text: hey guys Thomas Joseph here and today
I'm really excited to share with you a
muscle 101 now muscles you can buy them
at your supermarket they're readily
available these days or your fishmonger
if you're so lucky I'm gonna share with
you how to buy them how to store them
when you get them home how to clean them
and then a really simple way to cook
them in front of me here I have two
different types of muscles that you
might find stateside that is the
Atlantic blue muscle it has kind of a
black appearance here but there is a
slight blue tinge blue almost like
purpley tinge to the shell and then
there is this Pacific version which is
called the New Zealand green lipped
mussel if you find these in your
supermarket and you're able to get them
the method of preparation is really the
same so there's really no difference in
cooking these muscles they're just a
different variety now these are only two
of the many varieties that exist
these are marine mussels so they're
grown in saltwater and in talking about
harvesting or growing mussels the
majority of mussels out there in the
marketplace today are farm raised
and usually we kind of frown at that
phrase of farm raised seafood but what's
really great about farm raised mussels
is that they're good for the environment
so when I say farm raised I don't mean
they're kind of grown in pens or
anything like that but they're actually
cultivated on these long lines that kind
of string up from the bottom of the
ocean and float up to the top of the
water so that's where these mussels are
grown now muscles are actually filter
feeders so that means that they filter
out the waters and clean up the
environment so farmed mussels are
actually really a great thing and you
should pick them up whenever you can
find them because they do make a really
quick dinner as well so when you're at
your supermarket or your fishmongers if
you can buy mussels by the piece you
could certainly try to do that most
often they're sold in netted bunches so
already by the pound or the two-pound
batch if you do have the opportunity to
buy them by themselves you want to look
for mussels that are nice and
moist that the shells aren't dried out
you want to make sure that they're not
too heavy for their size if they're too
heavy that means that they might have
silt or dirt in the inside of the mussel
always with shellfish with fish give it
a good smell it shouldn't smell fishy at
all these actually smell like sweet
seawater and that's really what you're
looking for
now sometimes mussels have a little bit
of dirt or silt or even some barnacles
that might grow on the shell and so what
you need to do when you get them home is
give them a good scrub so I recommend
you get them home you take them out of
the netted bag that they're in you give
them a good scrub with a stiff bristled
brush and then you want to put them into
a container if you're gonna store them
for later in the day or for the next day
put them into a container or colander so
something that's perforated set over a
bowl and you want to put ice over the
top of them and you don't want to wrap
these in plastic wrap or cut off any air
supply because these are living when you
buy them and if you cut off the air
supply the mussels are gonna die so give
them a good scrub and then when you're
ready to cook the mussels the one thing
that you want to do is remove the beard
so the beard is actually this little
piece it almost looks like seaweed or
something like that that comes out of
the shell and this is actually the part
of the muscle that adheres to whether
it's a rock or if it's one of those
tethered lines for farmed mussels so
what you need to do is remove this but
in removing it what you're actually
doing is killing the mussels so you want
to make sure that you do this right
before you're cooking it because you
don't want to do this and then store
them for a day or two and it's really
easy to pull it off of the mussel and
that's really how you clean a mussel
it's really really simple guys so don't
be intimidated by this process at all so
again just give them a good brush with a
stiff bristle brush you're going to
gently pull off the beard here and then
you're ready to cook the mussels and one
other great thing about farmed mussel
since they're grown in water on lines
and they're not wild on rocks or on a
pier or anything like that or near the
dirt they're less likely to have grit in
them so it's a really great thing
because then you won't get any gritty
muscles so for the recipe that I'm using
today super simple way to prepare
muscles what I'm gonna do in a nice
large straight-sided skillet I have here
I'm gonna add two cups of white wine so
whatever your favorite white wine is you
could use it here now the reason I'm
using such a large wide pan is because
we want the muscles to cook evenly so if
you're using a tall narrow pot which
actually a lot of recipes say when
you're making muscles to use like a
Dutch oven or a deep pot unfortunately
what's gonna happen is the heat source
is on the bottom right so all of the
muscles on the bottom are gonna get
cooked while the ones on top aren't
really cooking at the same rate so you
might get some overcooked mussels
having a shallow pan will really help
here because it will help them cook
evenly and all the mussels we will be
done at the same time now to this white
wine here I'm going to add four cloves
of chopped garlic four shallots that
have been diced up a heaping half
teaspoon of coarse kosher salt and you
really just want this to kind of come
together you want the wine to start
steaming you want the garlic and shallot
to kind of infuse into this white wine
and this will then ultimately become our
wonderful broth that will serve with our
mussels now in total for this recipe for
this quantity of wine and shallot you
need four pounds of cleaned mussels and
that's what I have here so this mixture
here passed a simmer for a few minutes
so that the wonderful aromatics the
shallot and the garlic infused into the
wine before we add in our mussels so
it's been about five minutes here and
now it's time
to add the muscles I'm gonna increase
the heat to high now because I want to
cook these quickly and so I'm just gonna
add in my muscles try to avoid the ice
here we don't want to add any extra
moisture here because we want a really
rich flavorful broth we don't want to
dilute it down with any ice cubes again
try to situate your muscles in a nice
even layer so they cook evenly and I'm
going to cook these muscles covered and
they're basically gonna steam and open
up and that should take anywhere from
five to six minutes but it really
ultimately depends on the size of the
muscles so if you have little smaller
muscles which are totally fine younger
muscles they might take a little less
time but if you have big guys they might
take a little bit longer so I have all
the muscles in I'm gonna cover this
again it's high heat for about five to
six minutes depending on the size and
the muscles okay so it's been 5 minutes
and look at this you guys our lovely
muscles are open they're nice and plump
and to this I'm gonna add a little bit

now this is a big batch of muscles so
you can kind of gild the lily here with
this butter because what it's gonna do
is it's gonna melt into the broth and
it's gonna give a really nice richness
to the broth so just let this kind of
melt in stir up the muscles and then I'm
going to add a little bit of fresh herb
to brighten this up so this is a mixture

basil and you could really mix this up
you could add a little bit of chive you
